content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is an interesting puzzle. Requires some creative problem solving

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The goal is easy to understand, and the code is quite simple. I did it in Python 3.

I think it can be a COC of 5 or 10 minutes

And please put a test and a validator where the input is a "big" prime number such as 8191 or 9397 (or bigger, if you wish).
The case where the exponent is 1 could be not properly handled by the code of one of the competitors. ;-)

Please fix those :
- in the output "prime_number^power if the n is a prime power" : remove the word "the" ( "prime_number^power if n is a prime power")
 - in the generator of stub change "loop n write i^j or Not a prime power" with "write i^j or Not a prime power" (no loop is needed since you output only one result per input.
Suggestion : I would rephrase "The goal is to find the prime power if it exists and print Not a prime power if it does not exist" with "The goal is to find out whether the input is a prime power (print  the prime and the power separated by "^" in this case) or not (print "Not a prime power in this case")"
I enjoyed the challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Réalisable dans les temps + possibilité de faire la différence en terme de temps entre les différents joueurs
In the part (exemple of result). It could be a good option to show what people have to write in the Output if n it's not a prime power : "Not a prime power"

No need to use sys.exit(0) i thinks, and line 11 : no need to else just return false.

line 7 : no need to break because of the return

line 8 : just return True no ?

i think the limit of n is too large, even your solution can't pass if n = 1e9 + 7.
the time complexity of best solution may be O(sqrt(n)), and it cloud be hard for most people.

You should add formatting to the statement with {{ }} and some newlines where necessary. This is especially true for "Not a prime power". You can also check out other puzzles for how to format the Input and Output sections better.

Finally, constraints should be on [[n]] rather than on [[power]].

1. Goal section
(a) Please amend all the equalities (7=71 should be 7=7^1, etc).
(b) Please change "is exists" to "it exists".
(c) Please change "No prime power found if isn't exist" to "Not a prime power if it does not exist".

2. Input section.
Please change "prime number" to "prime power".

3. Output section:
(a) "primary number" should be "prime number".
(b) Please change "the number" to [[n]].
(c) "is a prime number" should be "is a prime power".

4. Constraints section:
Suggest to change as 1 ≤ [[power]] ≤ 30.

5. Please pay more effort to double check the contribution for avoidable mistakes before submission, thanks.
Yes i was to excited i did'nt check my mistakes
Thanks for the help. But i can't put the power as n in the constraints because n is the number in input. I just want to make it clear that the power cannot be upper than 30
I use sys exit because it will run forever looking for else prime power

Thanks for following them :)
In the Output section, you can remove the words "in this case" in the two lines.

Constraints are almost always written for the input, so you would write 1 <= [[n]] <= 2^9. This is useful from a coding perspective because now people understand that the input number is an int and not a long or something else - this can't be easily determined from just [[power]] alone.

If you're concerned about [[power]] itself, you can leave it in as well.
